author: Ann Mah
title: On Europe’s Goth Trail, From the Brontës to Byron
text:
Dracula not enough for you ? Need more literary scares? Here are some other spots to follow in the footsteps of other Gothic writers.
In Somerset, on England ’s southwestern coast, Samuel Taylor Coleridge composed several notable poems, including “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,” a forerunner of the Gothic Romantic movement. Today, Coleridge’s cottage is owned by the National Trust, and a 51-mile walking path called the Coleridge Way links his favorite spots.
In Haworth, West Yorkshire — about a hundred miles southwest of Whitby — the Brontë Parsonage , now a museum, was the home of the Brontë family, including Anne, Charlotte and Emily. Also a National Trust property, the sisters wrote their most popular novels here — including Charlotte’s “Jane Eyre” and Emily’s “Wuthering Heights” — surrounded by desolate moorland; bronte.org.uk .
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage Lake Geneva as Shelley and Byron Knew It MAY 27, 2011 Footsteps: On England’s Coast, Thomas Hardy Made His World MAY 8, 2015 In Cologny, Switzerland, near Lake Geneva, a group of Romantic writers — including Lord Byron, Mary Shelley and Percy Bysshe Shelley — spent a cold summer of debauchery at neighboring villas. Their evenings of ghost stories, wine and laudanum resulted in works like Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein,” a collection of poems by Byron including “The Prisoner of Chillon” and a short story by John William Polidori called “The Vampyre,” which may have influenced Stoker.
